bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Gustaf E. Lambert, June 16, 1937

div1.p: Andrus writes to Lambert regarding lobbying efforts for the bill recognizing Lambert and Ames.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Gustaf E. Lambert, June 16, 1937
div1.opener:
COPY
From Mrs Ames
J.H. ANDRUS
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N.J.
6-16-37
Dear Friend Lambert:
div1.p: I sent you a copy of my letter to Congressman Parnell.

Herewith I am enclosing his reply, together with copy of a second
letter I am mailing him today.

Am very sorry that his reply to my original letter is not more
encouraging but - in spite of this - have hope that your bill will
pass this session.

Have you made any effort to get other of the guinea pigs to write
in your behalf? It seems to me that every one of them would be glad
to do so if they thought it would do you any good.

I know that - as far as I am personally concerned - I am very
grateful to both you and Dr. Ames and will do anything I possibly
can to help. If you can think of anything else that is within my
power just let me know.
(It is now 11:30 p.m. - the “company” has gone - and I can finish.)

I am about the same except that I have a lot more pain than formerly.
The pain that used to center in my back has relocated in the back
of my neck.

Give Schweig my regards when you see him and tell him that I will
write him within a day or two as I now have a typewriter that I can
operate while lying on my back.

Would be glad to hear from you and to learn how you are getting along.
My interest in you and your welfare will last as long as I do.

Mrs. Andrus joins in sending kindest regards and best wishes to
Mrs. Lambert and yourself.
